Geography: Elsholtzia is grown in Jiangxi, Hebei, Henan, Anhui; the largest production is in Jiangxi.
Mosla is grown in Guangxi, Hunan, Hubei.
Maladies Treated: Catching cold during summer months (夏月外感風寒，內傷於濕)
Headache with no sweat (頭痛無汗)
Epigastric and abdominal pain (脘腹疼痛)
Medical Function: Diuretic effect: the volatile oil contained is excreted by the kidneys, promoting renal vasodilation and hyperemia and increasing filtration pressure.
Samples of Formulae:
Name of formula: Xiang Ru Yin (香薷飲)
Source: Tai Ping Hui Min He Ji Ju Fang (《太平惠民和劑局方》)
Application: cold or flu during summer; for patterns with summer-heat and dampness (夏季感冒，夾暑濕証).
Function: 解表清暑，健脾利濕.
Composition: Xiang Ru (Chinese Mosla Herb) 10 g, Hou Po (Magnolia bark) 5 g, Bai Bian Dou (Hyacinth bean) 5 g.
Preparation: Cut Xiang Ru and Hou Po into small pieces. Stir fry Bai Bian Dou until brown and smash. Put all herbs into a warm thermos and pour in boiling water. Cover and keep warm for 1 hour. Or boil with water on the stove and simmer for 45 minutes.
Contraindications: Do not use in case external deficient with instant sweating or yin deficient with heat. 表虚自汗，陰虛有熱者禁用.

Geography: Gelsemium elegans Benth.: Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Guizhou, Yunnan (China).
Maladies Treated: gastric cancer and other digestive system tumors
furuncle sores swelling toxins (癤瘡腫毒)
parasites (external use; smash and apply to affected area, remove after half an hour or may irritate the skin and form blisters)
rheumatoid arthritis (external use; smash and apply to affected area)
Medical Function: Effect on immune system: possible bi-directional modulation (enhancing and inhibiting)
Effect on skin: therapeutic effect on neurodermatitis and psoriasis
Samples of Formulae:
External use for parasites and rheumatoid arthritis: Smash the herb and apply to the affected area. Remove after half an hour or it may irritate the skin and form blisters.

For treatment of rheumatoid arthritis: gou teng (Uncaria stem with hooks) 30 g, fang feng (Saposhnikovia root) 6 g, du huo (Angelica pubescens root) 3 g. Grind into coarse powder, roll with paper, light with fire, and smoke the affected areas.
Contraindications:
Whole plant is toxic. Usually for external use only. The young leaves are especially toxic.

There is no effective antidote. Commonly used therapy: gastric lavage, promoting vomiting, and diarrhea.

Gelsemium elegans Benth. (Loganiaceae), a toxic plant indigenous to southeastern Asia, is well known among hill tribes as an effective means for committing suicide. A crude alkaloidal fraction from its leaves was isolated by conventional acid-base extraction. Tests in animals showed that the alkaloids exerted analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. At a lethal dose, the alkaloids produced violent clonic convulsions that led to respiratory failure. Since the convulsions could be prevented by pentobarbital or diazepam and potentiated by reserpine, it is postulated that the alkaloids act centrally against GABA action. PMID: 14522437 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLIA]
Notes:
Classical and veterinary notes on livestock: 《唐本草》 states: “People or livestock eating its leaves all die; goats that eat it become very fat; pigs eating it can treat heat-type diseases.” 《廣西中藥志》 records: “When a pig has poor appetite, feeding with it can increase appetite.” 《廣東中獸醫常用草藥》 notes: “Gou wen, when regularly given to pigs and sheep, has insecticidal, stomach-strengthening, and fattening effects.” H. Green (former superintendent of the Hong Kong Botanical Garden) reportedly added a small amount of gou wen leaves to pig feed; not only did the pigs not get poisoned, their skin and hair became glossier, showing a nourishing effect.

Editor’s note: Low γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) can lead to clonic convulsions.

The Chinese text additionally states: “北美鉤吻 (Gelsemium elegans Benth.) produced in the Americas.”
